instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00185: What is 820-00185? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Hello

Fun little one I belive will be an easy fix!

Here's what it does

- Power button doesn't turn machine on, but will allow us to turn off. (therefore not keyboard) 
- Computer will run on battery power alone, but not turn on when only battery is connected 
- Computer will auto power on when connected to DC charger and functions normally, however will auto power back on when shut down.

My "Guess" for what is going on here is that the laptop thinks there is no battery connected. 

SYS Detect L = 250mv approx, and I've changed batteries and DC in boards, plus an SMC reset. 
PPVBat = 7.5v

investigating further but any tips are appreciated :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Once machine is turned off with power button, can you turn it on again with power button?
Do NOT disconnect charger for this test.
Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button.

Is the battery recognized and charging?
PRAM reset done?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Hi

I can't turn it "on"with power button, as when it's plugged in it immediately turns back on. 

Battery is recognised and charging.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message: Pram and SCM had no effect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
It also restart if you turn it off via software from macOS?
Disconnect internal SSD and test with USB macOS.
Also test removing airport card.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Hi

Changed keyboard (just in case) no effect
Wifi Card - no effect
Shutdown using software - remained off and couldn't turn back on until disconnected battery. Pushing power button resulted in Amp drop from 0.33 to 0.15 approx while button pressed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Monitor <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> when you press power button.
Also check using <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  - 3.5v normal, then 0.4v when pushed with power button. 

Sorry not sure what you mean by " Check using <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR> pads" (This is where I checked what the voltage was)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
I mentioned that in case power button doesn't work properly.

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and be sure all 4 RTC signals have good signal (above 2.4V).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Hello,

Can you please explain how I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> ?

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 10mv with only battery connected.

I am not sure what an RTC signal is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Inside PCH schematic you will find clearly delimited RTC block; look in all PCH/CPU pages.
There are 4 RTC signals (DC, not clock) easy to find.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> must be tested with charger connected.

Press power button, or use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads instead, if you want to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 10mw with battery and charger
with charger only is still 10mw

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Machine turns on with charger alone (no battery)?

Check <SIGNAL>PCIE_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> level; be sure <RESISTOR>R1452</RESISTOR> is good.
Also check <SIGNAL>AP_PCIE_DEV_WAKE</SIGNAL> and <RESISTOR>R1449</RESISTOR>.

Compare other WAKE signals with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
yes machine turns on with no battery.

<SIGNAL>PCIE_WAKE_L</SIGNAL>   3.3v, resister tests at 9k ohms in diode mode.
 <SIGNAL>AP_PCIE_DEV_WAKE</SIGNAL>  0v (please note computer is "on" does it need to be off. (remember as this is difficult) <RESISTOR>R1449</RESISTOR> looks OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00185</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Macbook Air - powering on issues
threads.message:
Possibly PCH issue.
But you should compare all AWAKE signals against good working board.
